Thank you for this update! I really like your writing. I just want to add a few thoughts to the tax/medical care issue. Disclaimer, I am from Central Europe so a lot of the American discourse on taxes and especially the ‚Äúyou only deserve what you pay‚Äù mentality  sounds outright crazy to me. 1. Tax equality is not only about taxing earnings proportionally. If you have fixed taxes, such as value added taxes for food and stuff, high earners have a proportionally lower tax burden. Same if you don‚Äôt tax certain things that are more common with wealthy people, such as earnings from interest. I am sure that proportionally to your income, you don‚Äôt pay a lesser percentage in taxes. 2. The right to receive medical care should never ever be tied to contributions. Which is why a state cannot be run like a company. Please don‚Äôt ever feel shame for receiving medical care. It is a states responsibility for its citizens to provide it and the real shame in my opinion is that so many countries are failing in that aspect.
I love all the details this time OP!!!

I find the idea of NYC being "less safe" than Pittsburgh to be kinda funny, especially for someone this privileged. This thing is coming to every corner of this nation. While the quick spread in NY has been very scary, it also means that it's far ahead of other parts of the country in terms of the virus curve. NYC is also always going to be a priority on the food supply chain and in terms of medical innovation.   You are privileged to be able to stay home in your apartment and have health insurance - therefore, you are as safe in NY as you would be anywhere. Yo all the people in comment section that are mad about parents paying for stuff, I feel bad for you. Most young adults are still on family plans it just makes more financial sense. And maybe this is a cultural difference with Americans, but please try giving money to an Asian parent. I promise you'll regret it. There is absolutely nothing wrong with parents or boyfriends or whoever that pays for stuff, I don't understand why it offends people so much. The OP isn't expecting any of this to be paid, her family just wants to do it for her. Fellow user of out-of-network therapists here: just wanted to note what I recently found out about coverage for out-of-network services after you hit your deductible.  Although your plan probably states 70% covered, it usually means 70% of the <strong allowable amount</strong  is covered.  The allowable amount is usually calculated by reference to the Medicare rates for services (multiplied by some amount, e.g., 120%, 130%).  That's a long way of saying to prepare for the fact that insurance might not cover 70% of your $185 therapy sessions.  It might be closer to 70% of $120 - depends on how your sessions are coded.

I think OP has good intentions, but there were a lot of social-distancing missteps here that I didn't like. Your daughter should not be visiting her grandparents, for one - I understand parenting while working is challenging, but that's what you signed up for when you had her. Not many of you caught my comment about commiserating with my friends over first world problems (because I know that‚Äôs all we have). Many people have it much worse. However, this was a snap-shot of what my life is like, and I‚Äôm not going to apologize for not having the same struggles as others. You are a nightmare of a human being who is casually passing out medication that can be EXTREMELY DANGEROUS if not used correctly as prescribed BY A MEDICAL PROFESSIONAL, and you are endangering your nanny, your mother-in-law, and probably a bunch of other people. Do better.

I'm sorry but OP, you have some very problematic habits that you need to straighten out, including, but not limited to: - spending as much on non-essentials as you are when you have $237,000 in debt - violating social distancing in about 913345 ways - drug dealing?!?! - demonstrating a complete lack of self-awareness by openly admitting to a felony online, and brushing it off as a "suburban drug deal" - not being able to figure out how to make dinner without a meal kit  Your ignorant and privilege-filled post entirely encapsulates the injustice of mass incarceration. People of color get prison sentences all the time for less than what you did. You distributed a drug that you had a prescription for to someone who didn't, which the law considers to be a felony (as opposed to possession, which is a much lighter crime in the eyes of the law). Moreover, you might think "Ativan is a harmless suburban/white collar drug that's totally different from something like cocaine," but you would be completely wrong. Ativan is a benzodiazepine. In medical school we call these benzos for short. In our substance abuse course in med school, we spent around 10x the amount of time on benzos as on cocaine. Why? Because benzos not only cause overdose deaths (especially when mixed with alcohol), but also cause *withdrawal deaths*. Cocaine doesn't cause withdrawal, but benzodiazepines do, and that can be fatal. Using benzodiazepines in the absence of a medical diagnosis is incredibly irresponsible.

For all of you out there that think fulltime RVing is great. Remember, unless you've got an enormous amount of money put away to live on after your in your 60s. It not a good idea to quit your job and take off. There are bunches of people out there that have done that without thinking ahead about there life when they're old. The older you get the more medical situations show up. Most people below 40 don't realize this. We been RVing for 12 years now. and we are retired so our trips are 3 to 5 months at a time. So we're pretty much fulltiming it when we're on the road. We don't have to worry about this covid 19 because we didn't sell our house. We paid it off before we started RVing.   We waited till we were debt free to do it. We worked hard to be able to do pretty much anything we want to do and we don't have to worry about money. Were 71 now and have years to RV left. If you can work from home then fulltime RVing is possible. Otherwise don't quit your day job to try this.  Most people doing this are not going to tell you anything negative because it won't make them look like they made the right decisions.   Save up the money and pay off the house and cars and credit cards. And research RVs for at least a year before buying one. All RVs break down whether they're new or not. It can be a good thing to buy used because someone else has paid for the problems they have. We pull a 37 foot 5th wheel with a Silverado crew-cab long bed truck. 7 solar panels and 4-300 amp batteries.

To those who are looking at law school like OP- If you think that your first semester will likely be online, I would wait a year. (Although I know it's hard to predict what the world will look like in August).  The first year of law school is hard and causes mental health issues galore- and that is even when you're able to be there in person, to make friends with your classmates, etc. I am graduating from law school in a few weeks and I can't think of anything worse or more challenging than starting your first semester of law school online.  In my opinion, it would be better to wait a year and have an in-person law school experience all the way through.

This comment is not directed to you specifically OP, because you seem like a sweet person who is aware of your privilege.  However, I wish people would use the world "privileged" instead of "lucky" when referring to parental or family support.  "Lucky" makes it sound random, whereas "privileged" acknowledges the systems in place (racism, classism, etc.) that allow some families to accrue and pass on wealth and opportunity to their children.  I say this as a person who has privilege both by birth and by marriage.  I have worked somewhat hard for the things I have, but I have also achieved financial stability and comfort because I have ALWAYS had some sort of safety net, and opportunities available to me because of my privileged status.  Just my two cents and again I don't mean to pick on you OP, I just hope to change the conversation around privilege!

OP here,  I know a lot of people have questions about my diet (because of course we all love talking about food ‚ò∫Ô∏è). I have done multiple elimination diets over the last decade, from weeks to months at a time, and I usually eat a low carb, almost zero sugar, high fat/protein diet. I am confident that dairy and artificial sweeteners are not a trigger for me based on past experiments (I know they‚Äôre not ‚Äògood‚Äô for you, but we all need a little vice. As a treat.). I started the FODMAP experiment to identify veggies that are hurting my gut as I usually stick to mostly meats/veggies and I am highly allergic to a lot of fruits which are too high in sugar for me anyways (no more peaches or apples ever!).  As an update- since the time I‚Äôve written this, I have gotten much more on track and will be permanently cutting out cashews, peas, broccoli, and soy (and limiting my artificial sweeteners for good measure- I‚Äôm so sad).  I‚Äôve also been continuing to track my spending and it‚Äôs crazy how much a specialized diet controls your spending options- I wish I could get by on just a head of cauliflower for dinner and that quality protein was cheaper.   Thanks to everyone who had helpful advice and the other folks who shared their gut issues, I love you all!

OP, I just wanted to pop in and offer some support. I went through the same thing about just over a year ago, and had to have the LEEP procedure. I was 26 at the time. It was super stressful and I have totally been in your shoes. A couple of things that helped me: my OBGYN recommended I start taking a supplement called Oncovite, which I started taking before the procedure... when they biopsied the tissue they removed from me, my doc told me that the abnormal cells were gone, and I‚Äôve had clear paps ever since. I absolutely know everyone has a different experience and no two bodies are the same, but I wanted to share some of my experience and offer a bit of hope. Secondly, I strongly believe that my aggressive efforts to drastically minimize the stress in my life played a huge role in keeping me healthy. I was also working as a designer, and also had dreams of becoming a freelance photographer full-time. I think my job was putting invisible stress on me, and ironically when I did quit that job and start freelancing (which is what I do now, full time) it took away the stress...I think because I am earning more, even though it isn‚Äôt a ‚Äústeady‚Äù paycheck.  It is incredible what stress can do to the body, and we have to take care of our whole selves.

Please, please, please make sure to have regular anal exams in addition to vaginal exams and cervical Pap smears. I had multiple abnormal Pap‚Äôs and LEEP procedures 15 years ago and was recently diagnosed with anal cancer, which is also caused by HPV.  I never had any anal exams because I wasn‚Äôt practicing anal sex so the cancer had been growing there all these years.  If you haven‚Äôt already, get the HPV vaccine. It‚Äôs FDA approved for women to age 45 now. I‚Äôve had surgery and radiation and the cancer might still come back. All of this could have been completely prevented.

Hi OP! I‚Äôm sorry you had to go through such a painful/annoying medical procedure twice, not to mention deal with the fear and uncertainty.   I just want to say, there‚Äôs no such thing as an ‚Äúimmune boosting diet‚Äù. Any diet that claims to boost your immune system is pseudoscience. There are of course plenty of other reasons to eat vitamin-filled fruits and veggies, as well as lean protein sources, so there‚Äôs no harm in that.   I totally understand wanting to try something that claims to boost your immune system or claims to be ‚Äúanti-cancer.‚Äù  Illness and cancer are scary, and it would be nice to think we could cure them with magic diets. It just doesn‚Äôt work that way (though certain cancers.. eg colon cancer.. are linked to certain less healthy diets).   I hope you got the answers you wanted from your colposcopy. Also don‚Äôt be afraid to switch doctors to find one who talks to you more. Listening to your patients is arguably one of the most important things for a doctor to do.

In my mid-20's I had several abnormal paps and got diagnosed with strains 16 and 18 of HPV. Also had a colonoscopy and was given all of the general advice about the body naturally clearing HPV. I'm now 30 and the last few paps I've had have been clear!  One thing that I don't see mentioned in this thread and that finally clicked for me was that even if you are taking all of the vitamins in this world, reducing your stress etc. if you're still sleeping with the same guy and not using condoms, chances are that you will continue to be reinfected with the HPV.  My gyno had advised me that I should be using condoms with my boyfriend, at least until I'd cleared the virus, I ignored her advice at that time. It wasn't until I broke up with the boyfriend I was with during my abnormal paps that I noticed that all my paps since about 6 months post breakup have been clear. Honestly everything else about my lifestyle and health has stayed the same.  This might be obvious, but I wanted to share what I've learned from my own experience (and lack of listening to professionals in the first place!) in case it makes a difference to someone going through the stress of abnormal paps :)

OP, I immediately stopped reading to comment when I got done with day one. I'm 25, and have been getting abnormal pap smears for the last several years because I have high-risk HPV. I have strains 16 and 18, the two strains that have the highest possibility to make my cervical cells become cancerous. I'm surprised that you had a colposcopy done at 23‚Äîthat's pretty young, and most gynos don't recommend those until you're at least 25 because your immune system is stronger when you're younger. I got my first colposcopy done this year, and it was the scariest thing I've ever had to do. My results from my colposcopy (to make a very long, boring story short) stated that even though I have abnormal cells on my cervix, they're pretty much dormant, so I just need to get a pap smear done every year. As scary and terrifying abnormal paper smears are,I want you to know that it honestly is totally normal. You're doing the right thing in getting it checked out and monitored though. The more you stay on top of it, the higher your recovery is IF they find something in the future. I do want to also reassure you just because you have abnormal cells on your cervix, that doesn't mean that you're GOING to get cervical cancer. It just means those cells COULD. COULD doesn't mean WILL. As long as you're taking good care of yourself, eating right, exercising, doing things to boost your immune system, and going to regular doctor's appointments, I PROMISE you you will be okay. :-) You've got this!

OP here! I did notice I forgot to mention a few things :) I cleared up some horse money questions in the comments below! Also, my health insurance is 100% employer paid. I'm super grateful for that and being able to get off my family's insurance plan early! I contribute 55$ a month with my employer matching that = $110 a month to my HSA. I use this to cover my monthly chiropractor visits (Back pain, am I right?) and the leftover I plan to invest. My company offers investment plans at the end of each fiscal year to invest "left over" money from your HSA and I plan to take full advantage of that. My retirement is currently 3% of my income for now. I plan to up that come fall. As apart of my hire, I started at $50k a year and in 6 months (September) receive a $5k raise, so that will put my annual salary at $55,000 a year. They will reevaluate my income and put in for another raise once I graduate. I started at my company in June of 2019 as an intern, caught on very quickly, and got the opportunity to come on full time!   You all have been so amazing and supportive in the comments section! I love interacting with everyone and hearing questions or their stories! :)

I suggest doing something in a group regularly as a good way to make friends. Showing up week after week allows you the time to build a friendship, and a common topic to discuss. Sport, volunteering, an adult education course, I speak from experience, are all good ways of making friends.

I'm a 22 year old and I've also noticed that it's hard to make friends my own age in a new place. I think a big factor is that in your early 20s, many people in the area have been there since high school/college, and thus already have established friend groups. As you get older, more people start to move around, and there are more people your age looking for new friends.

I‚Äôll just leave this here.

I'm an epidemiologist who volunteered as a contact tracer for the occupational health department at our big hospital system. Past tense because there were so many cases among health care workers, occupational health gave up on contact tracing.  Your partner has been exposed. It's nearly a given. I can't tell you how many clinicians (e.g., people who theoretically know what to look for) from nurses to respiratory therapists to attending physicians to department heads and everyone in between who kept coming to work despite having "a tickle in their throat" (sometimes for WEEKS even) that later led to a positive COVID-19 test. If not a positive patient, then a coworker. If not this week, then next. I would really urge to think of it not as a possibility, but as an inevitability and the question is only when.  It's the worst, because obviously there's no option to not come to work if you're serving in such an essential role. But it means you, OP, can't just be careful, you have to be militant about precautions and distancing. Please sit down and take the time to take a hard look at how much contact and how much risk you're actually running here.

I wanted to share my opinion on your husband's reactions in case he's been having things like this happen a lot lately. I was in his same position just over a year ago due to something called Chronic Spontaneous Urticaria - basically random hives and allergic reactions to no specific trigger. My body and immune system were on overdrive largely due to stress and anxiety (I was dealing with unemployment at the time), and I also had a couple of trips to the ER after a few severe reactions. I found that cutting out dairy, soy and gluten made a huge difference in the severity and frequency of my hives, along with taking daily antihistamines.   It's a horrible feeling to have these unknown reactions, but eventually after working with my allergist and naturopath I was able to cut out the antihistamines and replace them with natural supplements, but it's different for every person I've talked to about this condition. I'd recommend looking up support groups on Facebook, and wish you both the best of luck!

I have severe anxiety and OCD and your husband/bf's choking/throat swallowing thing is something I went through. When I have anxiety/OCD bad flare ups I get this weird symptom where I constantly think I am choking - sometimes on food, sometimes on water, sometimes on nothing; also it feels like I have lumps and obstructions in my throat. I have gone to the ER for it multiple times, I ended up in ENT physical therapy. My physical therapist realized it was psychological and had me do a swallow test where I swallowed food with dye in it so I could see it on an x-ray in a lab and SEE that I had no obstruction and that helped a lot. But basically unless I am on a high dose of antidepressants I get to a point where I feel like I am choking or obstructed all the time.  His panic and then ER visit was very VERY familiar to me. Something to consider.

R29: the "net worth" field as-is is pretty darn useless.  it seems no one really knows how to calculate it. refer to the diarists with 200K+ in student and consumer debt who then have a positive net worth listed. unless these people somehow also have hundreds of thousands of equity in their homes or massive trust funds, this can't possibly be right.  what would be much more meaningful (and likely more consistently calculated) is an inventory of assets. for example, here she says she has $100K net worth. is that tied up in a home she owns? 401K? liquid assets? did she inherit it? saying "my net worth is $100k" is not at all useful information in painting a financial picture...especially for a 25 year old making $80k a year

Hi OP! I know you mention anxiety/depression and I struggle with same. Have you considered limiting or cutting out alcohol and caffeine? I'm not saying this with a preachy or judgy tone at all. I know different things work for different people. It did help me quite a bit personally so that's the only reason I'm throwing this out there. :)

Something I'll never understand is congratulating someone for working long hours, especially for relatively low pay. Why? She didn't mention that her work brings her so much joy that she truly can't leave and go home.   Doesn't matter if you're a lawyer, but for salaried workers, you're setting up the expectation that one person can do the job of two or more people, giving away your free time and making your hourly wage so much lower if you typically work 60 hours/week. What's the glory in that?  Edited to add: this comment doesn't apply for workers who get overtime pay or comp time in exchange for working beyond 40 hours/week.

Is it just me or do her monthly expenses as listed total up to more than her take home salary at the end of the month? Perhaps she doesn't actually put as much towards savings every single month as she says, but still that stuff always irks me because it's setting up such a different picture on the outset than what's actually real.   That being said, I loved this MD! Great picture of a mid-30s gal in the city, and OP seemed like someone I'd love to grab a drink and be friends with. I do think that OP realizes overall how great her privilege is at not having any debt and owning her apartment. It might be forgotten in moments where she expects her friends in Big Law to cover more of the tab (while forgetting that although they may have huge salaries, many of them probably also have huge huge debt and less overall privileges than she does.)But alas, we're all human and we all have our moments. OP, you're great. Continue being you.

I know you didn't want public health advice, but if your family has symptoms and are suspected COVID-19 patients, you SHOULD NOT BE LEAVING YOUR HOME until 14 days after symptoms are resolved. There is also evidence, by the way, that the dosage of virus you receive matters - so snuggling with your kids and sleeping in the same bed with your partner while they are sick is also very ill advised. (This is, by the way, also why many young doctors and nurses are dying - they think - high virus loads that they are exposed to on the job.) I liked the food descriptions in the diary. OP, wanted to respond on two things:<ul <li Vulvodynia: I had severe vaginismus for as long as I can remember. It was mainly caused by physical pelvic floor issues, but further exacerbated by pain whenever I tried penetrative sex. My first five years of being sexually active were really bad and I felt a lot of guilt, which seeped into every aspect of my life. I eventually bought a set of soft silicone dilators (google them) and used guided self-hypnotism therapy (you can download it) to eventually be able to insert up to the largest size. I was still scared of actual sex so went to a physical therapist who specialized in this. After just two sessions, I was able to have penetrative sex. Mind you, the whole process took a year and a half. My point being, there's lots of help for these issues - I was on an online group for a while which really helped. Don't beat yourself up over this; it is indeed something you can plan for and control. </li <li Face masks: I have been using DIY face masks my whole life. My go to recipe is chickpea flour, turmeric, yogurt. Sometimes I add a squeeze of lemon juice but do this only if your skin is very oily.  </li </ul

RE: Vulvodynia - I struggled with it for 4.5 years before I finally found a doctor that believed me and put me on a treatment. I stopped using Xulane (BC path) as it was causing the tissue to dry out and become inflamed and started using a topic testosterone / estradiol gel. After two months, I could use tampons. I started going to pelvic floor physical therapy and started using dilators and was cured within 1.5 months of weekly appointment + daily dilating. Now, I don't need to dilate and have successful and pleasant penetrative sex.   It's frustrating that women's sexual pain is not believed. After diagnosis, I went from unbearable burning pain when trying to insert a finger to fully cured in less than 4 months. There is a cure - it may not be as straightforward as my story but it's treatable. Good luck!

Hi OP as a former animal foster parent I have a few tips. You shouldn't be paying for anything out of pocket, if you need toys, food, etc. the humane society should be giving those to you. Second, 10-12 weeks is the hardest time and be prepared for damage to your apartment. This is essential where your kittens are in their toddler phase. They will be rambunctious so rambunctious. Finally if you have a cat that hisses when you come near, and is scared try putting a little wet food on your fingers. It will lead to a positive association.
